speaker: E
text: Sure. Absolutely. So, you know, Ash, thank you for saying that about Filecoin. I have also found that it really is a very easily understandable use case, and so, so important for cryptocurrency technology to have those very clear use cases. And so when it comes to Filecoin, Filecoin basically uses the concept of programmable money to create a decentralized file storage network. So basically, if you have extra storage space on your computer hardware, you can rent it out to others who will pay you to store their files. Or more accurately, it's actually pieces of their files, so that only the file owner can put those pieces back together. And so a computer program is going to regularly check to make sure that those files, files are still being stored on your computer, and if so, it automatically compensates the storage provider with cryptocurrency. So that might sound like a bit of a niche use case, but we actually believe that this is a foundational technology for the next generation of the Internet, because today's Internet is centralized, and the vast majority of data that's making up the many websites we use every day is sitting in a warehouse that's owned by either Amazon, Microsoft, or Google, really just. And you'll often see one of those companies suffer a blackout, and then vast swaths of the web go down for hours, which is the problem with having these single points of failure. So we really believe that you can create a better version of the web if you combine the storage capacity and computing power on all of our individual devices into this supercomputer like network, and store many copies of data across those devices. And so this is a more decentralized version of the web, where websites can stay up even if some nodes fail and the availability of information isn't dependent on any one server or company. So that's a little bit about Filecoin. And the Filecoin foundation is the steward of the Filecoin community, and also facilitates governance of the Filecoin network.

And we actually had surpassed one exabyte of storage capacity within just a few weeks of launch, and we now have 19 exabytes of storage capacity. So to give you an idea of sort of how big that is, that could store all of the written works of mankind in every language from the beginning of recorded history to today, 20 times. Overdose. So just a massive amount of computing power and storage capacity, and representing about 1% of digital storage capacity worldwide, which is just an incredible amount of storage. And we are really seeing some amazing use cases of that. For example, just as one example, the Starling lab, which is a project of Stanford and USC, is using the Filecoin network to permanently preserve the USC Shoah Foundation's archive of 55,000 video testimonials of genocide survivors. So you're really seeing this being used to store humanity's most important information, which is really our mission.

text: Absolutely. Fully open source. Anyone can use the Filecoin network. Anyone can use it to store files? Anyone can use it to store other people's files.

speaker: D
text: Okay, so can you explain to everybody a little bit about proof of replication and proof of space time? I mean, we all heard of proof of stake, proof of work. How does this work, exactly?

speaker: E
text: Sure. So proof of work is the proof system that bitcoin uses, proof of stake. Ethereum has recently moved over to. And file coin actually has its own proof system that's called proof of space time, and then also proof of replication. And so this is. This is a totally different, um, type of proof system, uh, that, um, filecoin developed. And it is also, um, much more energy efficient, um, than. Than proof of work, for example. Um, and basically, um, proof of space time. Uh, I think the simple way to think about it is basically being able to prove that you're continuing to store files, um, someone else's files, um, and being compensated for. For being able to prove that you're continuously storing someone's files, such that if you end up not storing someone's files, you will be punished for it, basically. And that's how we ensure that files continue to be stored reliably over time.

speaker: D
text: Fantastic. And then, so let's go back to your impact, because, marta, you have made such, I mean, an amazing impact in the sense that you've been supporting the Internet archive. Why is that such an important transaction?

speaker: E
text: Yeah, absolutely. So, really, our mission at the Filecoin foundation is to preserve humanity's most important information. That is what the Filecoin network is intended to do. And so we actually work with dozens of different organizations and project partners who are doing just that, who are storing humanity's most important information. And we help them do that on the decentralized web so that they don't have these issues with single points of failure and to make sure that their information can continue to be stored over time. So the Internet Archive is just one example of that. We do a ton of work with the Internet Archive, making sure that their sort of backups of the whole web are stored reliably on the decentralized web. And we also have a big partnership with the Internet Archive to actually store government data sets. We announced a big project called Democracy's Library with the goal of basically taking all government data sets and data, and we do mean all, and putting it onto the decentralized web to make sure it's preserved over time. But it's not just the Internet archive. We also have dozens of other project partners. So some examples are witness and open archive and HR DAG are all storing human rights data. And making sure that human rights data gets preserved and isn't subject to disappearing because of single points of failure. Freedom of the press foundation. I could go on and on. This is really a big part of our mission. It isn't just about cryptocurrency. This is about the decentralized web and making sure information is preserved.

speaker: C
text: By the way, talking of which, just to expand the conversation a little bit more broadly, obviously, we've been talking about Filecoin here, Marta, but you're involved much more generally in the space, I should say. You're a Stanford law graduate. You have a very serious background in the law, and you've been writing and speaking about some of the things that are happening from a legal, regulatory, and legislative framework. Recently, you published an op ed on the Coindesk website talking about the Digital Asset Money Laundering act that was currently recently introduced by Senator Elizabeth Warren. Give us a big picture take on where you think we are in the space more generally, but also specifically with relationship to that particular bill, the direction you think we're headed now.

speaker: E
text: Yeah, absolutely. So Senator Warren and also Senator Marshall on the republican side introduced this bill at the FTX hearing in the Senate. And this bill is called the digital Asset Anti Money Laundering act. And it's really quite a shocking bill that would do absolutely nothing to address the problems with FTX, but would really grind the entire blockchain and cryptocurrency ecosystem in the United states to a halt. It is really, I think, one of the most egregious bills we've seen in terms of targeting software developers and targeting privacy technologies. So, first of all, the bill would require basically every participant in blockchain networks to register as money service businesses, and that includes miners wallet creators, both for self hosted and custodied wallets, and then miners validators, nodes, and then also sort of as a catch all, any independent network participant that has control over network protocols. So anyone who fits into one of those categories, which is extremely broad. Right. Basically, anyone in a blockchain network is going to need to register with the government as a money service business, develop and maintain these very complicated anti money laundering programs, collect the personal information of every person who's using their software, and automatically file reports about those people. Right. So the problem with that is, of course, you can't comply with that. It's not just too onerous for individuals to comply with that, but it is actually impossible. Right. Because, for example, if you are, let's say, you're a validator or a miner, you have absolutely no way of knowing whose transactions you're facilitating. That's the point of the technology. So it really would grind the entire ecosystem to a halt. And then the second thing it does that is really kind of shocking. Is it a basically says that all of those network participants that I just mentioned can't interact with privacy enhancing technologies, including privacy coins, which is, I mean, really? So it's sort of effectively banning in blockchain networks the use of anonymity enhancing technologies or privacy coins. And to me, this is really quite shocking and expansive. I hope it's not going anywhere, but I think it's really important that we push back on this kind of bill being introduced, because when there is an omnibus bill that's, that's going through and they're pulling language from other bills, we definitely do not want them to pull from this one.

speaker: C
text: Let me follow up real quick. You know, this isn't a direct quote, but you've talked before about this misconception that crypto isn't already regulated. The idea that it's being regulated at the endpoints, at the on ramps, so that this isn't a totally unregulated space. Talk a little bit about how you see that framework and why you think it's adequate to protect against things like AML, KYC and OFAC compliance.

speaker: E
text: Yeah, absolutely. So, you know, I really do think that people, even in the cryptocurrency space, I think people believe that cryptocurrency is unregulated. And in fact, that's not true. This space is heavily regulated. The on ramps and the off ramps where people are buying and selling and costing cryptocurrency in the United States are these very heavily, heavily regulated entities. So these are chartered banks or trust companies or state licensed money transmitters. And they have minimum capital requirements, and they have to post bonds, and they open their doors to yearly examinations, and they register with FinCEN and their financial institutions under the Bank Secrecy act and just goes on and on and on. And yet somehow we assume, or we think that this space is unregulated, and it's just not true. And I think one of the major issues that you're seeing with the reaction to FTX is people are looking at FTX and saying, oh, we need more regulation around cryptocurrency exchanges in the United States. That's not true. In fact, FTX was not in the United States. It was in the Bahamas. Right. And if it had been in the United States, then it would have been following all these heavy regulations that already exist for the on ramps and off ramps and places where people store cryptocurrency.

speaker: C
text: Wendy, that's such a great point, and I'm glad you brought it up. Just talking about web three, I don't think we really defined it on this show.
